objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#traditional-approach-to-portfolio-construction
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#traditional-approach-to-portfolio-construction
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Traditional approach to portfolio construction
The traditional approach to constructing a private clientâ€™s portfolio views risk in an overall portfolio context and consistent of the following steps:

Identify appropriate asset classes for the clientâ€™s portfolio.
Develop capital market expectations (i.e., expected returns, standard deviations, and correlations of asset classes).
Determine asset class weights for the portfolio, consistent with the clientâ€™s risk tolerance for the overall portfolio.

mean-variance optimization
Key considerations when implementing the portfolio include:

Use of active or passive management (or a combination) for each asset class.
Manager selection
Degree of hedging required (e.g., for currency exposure)
currency management
Choosing asset location (e.g., placing investments that generate significant levels of taxable income into accounts that offer tax exemption).




Untitled





Untitled

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#goals-based-investing
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#goals-based-investing
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Goals-based investing
Goals-based investing essentially follows the same steps as the traditional approach to portfolio construction, the critical difference being that instead of constructing a single portfolio, the private wealth manager creates separate portfolios for each of the clientâ€™s goals. Mean-variance optimization, which can be structured to maximize expected returns for a given level of risk or to meet a specified probability of success, is carried out for each goal portfolio rather than for the entire portfolio.
This is another illustration of behavioral portfolio theory, which suggests that investors construct their portfolios in layers with different return expectations and risk perceptions for each layer.
With goals-based investing, clients may find it easier to specify their risk tolerance, as this is expressed for each goal portfolio rather than for the clientâ€™s entire portfolio. A key disadvantage of this approach is that the clientâ€™s entire portfolio may not be mean-variance efficient.



Untitled

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#portfolio-reporting
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#portfolio-reporting
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Portfolio reporting

Performance summary for the current period

Be prepared to identify three or four items from the preceding list that could be added to a clientâ€™s portfolio report to improve the clientâ€™s understanding of portfolio performance.
Note that the horizon mismatch between quarterly (or annual) portfolio reports and the significantly longer investment horizon of a client can potentially distort a clientâ€™s perception of the portfolioâ€™s long-term effectiveness.

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#portfolio-review
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#portfolio-review
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Portfolio review
A portfolio review enables the private wealth manager to reassess a clientâ€™s IPS and investment strategy in light of recent performance to determine if changes are required. A portfolio review typically addresses the following areas:

Appropriateness of clientâ€™s existing goals and investment parameters and if any changes are required.
Rebalancing of portfolio asset allocation to target allocation or ranges.

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#goal-achievement
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#goal-achievement
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Goal achievement
An investment program is considered a success if it fulfills a clientâ€™s goals within the specified risk parameter. Due to the ongoing nature of the investment program, the criteria for success should be whether it is still likely to meet the clientâ€™s longer-term goals (e.g., using capital sufficiency analysis) without a significant change in the original strategy.

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#process-consistency
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#process-consistency
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Process consistency

Has the wealth manager implemented an investment strategy that is consistent with the clientâ€™s goals and investment preferences?

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#portfolio-performance
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#portfolio-performance
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Portfolio performance
Portfolio performance can be measured against an absolute performance benchmark (e.g., 5% fixed return) or relative to a passive benchmark (e.g., return on a domestic stock index). The impact of investment risk can be evaluated by comparing the risk-adjusted return (e.g., Sharpe ratio) of the clientâ€™s portfolio and and appropriate benchmark and by comparing the portfolioâ€™s downside risk with the clientâ€™s risk tolerance.
Questions are likely to ask you to evaluate a clientâ€™s investment program against the three criteria previously discussed. An investment program can be said to be successful only if it achieves success on all three criteria.



Untitled





Untitled

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#ethical-considerations
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#ethical-considerations
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Ethical considerations

Fiduciary duty and suitability
Assessing the suitability of potential investments for a private client is an important component of a wealth managerâ€™s fiduciary duty.


Know your customer
KYC requirements are covered in Standard III(C) suitability.


Confidentiality


Conflicts of interest
Private wealth managers may face potential conflicts of interests if their fee- or commission-based compensation structure influences the provision of investment advice and recommendations to their clients.


Compliance considerations

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#mass-affluent-segment
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#mass-affluent-segment
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Mass affluent segment
ëŒ€ì¤‘ë¶€ìœ ì¸µ
The mass affluent segment requires a wide range of wealth management services, such as portfolio construction, risk management, and retirement planning. It is characterized by a larger number of clients per wealth manager and greater use of technology in delivering services such as account creation and portfolio reporting. Due to the larger client-to-wealth manager ratio, wealth managers do not tend to tailor their portfolio management approach for each client.

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#high-net-worth-hnw-segment
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#high-net-worth-hnw-segment
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
High-net-worth (HNW) segment
The HNW segment exhibits a smaller number of clients per wealth manager compared to the mass affluent segment. Wealth management services provided in this segment are more likely to concentrate on tailored investment solutions, tax planning, and estate planning. The portfolios of HNW clients are more likely to contain sophisticated strategies (e.g., derivatives-based) and alternative investments. Estate planning (ìƒì†ì„¤ê³„) considerations may also result in longer investment horizons and greater risk capacity.

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#ultra-high-net-worth-uhnw-segment
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#ultra-high-net-worth-uhnw-segment
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Ultra-high-net-worth (UHNW) segment
This segment is likely to have multigenerational investment horizons, complex tax and estate planning, and a more comprehensive range of service requirements, including ancillary service (e.g., travel planning) and advice on luxury investments (e.g., art and automobiles). The UHNW segment has a relatively low client-to-manager ratio because of the need to provide a highly customized service to client.
A UHNW wealth manager typically manages the portfolios of multigenerational family members, Â requiring consideration of family governance and inheritance issues. UHNW clients are more likely to be serviced by a client relationship team that includes legal, tax, and investment exerts in addition to a relationship manager. Some UHNW individuals may also choose to employ a family office of financial experts to manage their assets.

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#robo-advisors
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#robo-advisors
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Robo-advisors
Robo-advisors are automated wealth management advisors that assist private clients with their portfolio management needs. Robo-advisors gather client information using online questionnaires and recommend an appropriate asset allocation for the clientâ€™s portfolio using mean-variance optimization or alternative techniques. The clientâ€™s portfolio is constructed using exchange-traded funds or mutual funds and monitored on an ongoing basis.
Because of the automated client interface, the costs associated with using robo-advisors are lower than the fees charged by traditional private wealth managers.

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#main-categories-of-taxes
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#main-categories-of-taxes
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Main categories of taxes

Income tax (earnings) - paid by individuals, corporations, and other legal entities on various types of income including wages, rents, interest, and dividends.
Capital gain tax (earnings) - calculated on the price appreciation (e.g., proceeds minus cost) upon disposition of an asset. Tax rates of capital gains often differ from income.
Wealth/property tax (ownership) - paid annually on the value of assets held (frequently real estate). Has lower rates than income or capital gains taxes because wealth/property tax is assessed on the asset value.
Stamp duties (purchases, ì¸ì§€ì„¸) - Tax on purchase price of real estate or financial assets
Wealth transfer tax - examples include inheritance, estate, or gift taxes. May be imposed on the transferee or the transferor.

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#investment-income
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#investment-income
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Investment income
Fixed-income instruments generate interest income, which is taxed at regular income tax rates in most jurisdictions.
Double taxation occurs when earnings are taxed first in the corporation, followed by some or all the after-tax corporate earnings being paid out to investors as dividends, which are then taxed as well. As a result of the double taxation, many jurisdictions have provisions to reduce the level of taxation of the dividends (second level). Qualified dividends are an example of dividends taxed at a lower rate. Qualified dividends are dividends from shares in local and certain foreign corporations where the investor has owned the shares for a certain amount of time (e.g., 60 days) on an unhedged basis.

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#capital-gains
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#capital-gains
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Capital gains
data:image/svg+xml;supportsDarkMode=1;base64,
data:image/svg+xml;supportsDarkMode=1;base64,
The net sales price is the price after deduction of commissions and trading costs. Often, the tax basis is simply the original cost of the asset. In some jurisdictions, there could be a â€œstep-upâ€ in basis to fair market value on the date of death with no capital gains taxes owing. In other jurisdictions, the step-up occurs upon death or departure in residency, but any unrealized gains would be taxed.
tax basis (ì·¨ë“ì›ê°€) ìƒí–¥ì¡°ì • â†’ ìƒì†ìì‚°ì˜ ê²½ìš° tax basis = fair market value
Realized capital gains occur upon the actual disposition of an asset. Unrealized capital gains are â€œpaper gains,â€ which represent appreciation on unsold items. In situations where there is a realized capital loss, most jurisdictions allow the realized capital loss to reduce any realized capital gains.
Depending on the holding period of the investments, the capital gains may be subject to a short-term (usually higher) rate or a long-term (usually lower) rate. The rationale behind the rate differentials is to encourage long-term investment and discourage short-term speculation. If countries have low long-term capital gains tax rates, this means that stocks are more tax-efficient investments than bonds, the latter of which are taxed at regular rates.
Stock has tax deferral effect.

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#real-estate-tax
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#real-estate-tax
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Real estate tax
When considering real estate as an investment (and not as a principal residence), only the net income is taxable in most cases. This means items such as interest, depreciation, and repairs are deductible against the gross income of the property. In the case of depreciation (e.g., straight line or declining over a specified number of years), the annual expense would reduce the cost base. Upon the ultimate sale of the property, there may be a recapture of depreciation if the proceeds of the sale exceed the propertyâ€™s depreciated cost base.

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#types-of-investment-accounts
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#types-of-investment-accounts
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Types of investment accounts
asset location
A taxable account (e.g., individual brokerage account) is taxed at the relevant rates for each type of investment income.

periodic taxation

A tax-deferred account (e.g., individual retirement account) allows for pretax contributions and tax-free accumulation, but all amounts are taxed at withdrawal as regular income.

taxation when withdrawal

A tax-exempt account (e.g., Roth IRA in the United States) allows for after-tax contributions to accumulate on a tax-free basis and with no taxes upon withdrawal.

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#types-of-tax-systems
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#types-of-tax-systems
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Types of tax systems
taxation on cross-border investment
A tax haven is a jurisdiction with very low or no tax rates for residents and foreign investors (e.g., Bermuda).
A territorial tax system taxes only income that is earned locally (e.g., Hong Kong SAR).
A worldwide tax system will impose taxes on all sources of income, which inevitably leads to double taxation on the same income by more than one jurisdiction. However, relief may be provided in the form of tax credits by the home jurisdiction for tax already paid in the source jurisdiction or bilateral tax treaties. Often, taxes are imposed on only residents of the jurisdiction, so it is crucial to determine the jurisdiction in which one is a resident. It is usually based on the amount of time spent in the jurisdiction (e.g., considered resident if living there fore 183 of 365 days of the year). Tie-breaker rules exist so that individual are not in the onerous position of being a resident in two jurisdictions simultaneously.



Untitled





Untitled





Untitled





Untitled

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#tax-efficiency
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#tax-efficiency
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Tax efficiency
Tax efficiency of various asset classes and investment strategies - tax minimization
A tax-efficient strategy results in relatively high after-tax returns compared to pretax returns. Frequently, equities have greater tax efficiency versus fixed income and real estate, for example. Common reasons include 1) lower tax rates on dividends and capital gains in many countries and 2) the ability to time securities dispositions to maximize tax benefits.



Untitled


Often, alternative assets are selected because of low correlations to traditional assets such as stocks and bonds. However, the tax laws pertaining to alternative assets (e.g., hedge fund strategies, partnerships) are usually far more complex than for traditional assets. As a result, the impact of alternative assets on portfolio risk and return should always be viewed from an after-tax and after-fee perspective.
Investments that emphasize high-yield (interest income) and/or high turnover are often tax inefficient. At the same time, timing must also be considered, and in that regard, a momentum strategy with higher turnover might initially be viewed as tax inefficient. However, momentum strategies are quite tax efficient in that they hold winners longer (thereby deferring tax on gains) and sell losers sooner (thereby realizing earlier to offset against any gains). As a general note, investment constraints that require managers to sell securities (and realize gains) and rebalance portfolios more frequently result in less tax efficiency (e.g., in some jurisdictions, short-term capital gains are taxed higher than long-term capital gains).



Untitled


There are four common metrics used in examining tax efficiency:

After-tax holding period return

Relevant taxes are computed and deducted when investments are disposed of
Accounts for interest income, dividend income, and realized gains/losses but not unrealized gains/losses

After-tax post-liquidation return

An extension of what was just listed but there is an assumption of overall portfolio disposition after a specific period (e.g., 5 or 10 years)
This measure accounts for unrealized gains/losses.

After-tax excess returns

Either of the metrics just listed compared to a benchmark value

Tax-efficiency ratio

After-tax annualized total return versus pretax annualized total return





Untitled

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#after-tax-holding-period-return
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#after-tax-holding-period-return
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
After-tax holding period return
\[
R' = [(value_{1} - value_{0}) + income - tax] / value_{0}
\]
data:image/svg+xml;supportsDarkMode=1;base64,
Alternatively, \(R' = R - (tax / value_{0})\)
data:image/svg+xml;supportsDarkMode=1;base64,
Tax is estimated based on interest and dividends received plus capital gains/losses realized, each multiplied by the relevant tax rate.

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#after-tax-post-liquidation-return
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#after-tax-post-liquidation-return
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
After-tax post-liquidation return
\[
R_{PL} = [(1 + R^{'}_{1})(1 + R^{'}_{2})...(1 + R^{'}_{n}) - (\text{liquidation tax} / \text{final value})]^{1 / n} - 1
\]
\[
\text{liquidation tax} = (\text{final value} - \text{tax basis}) * \text{tax rate on capital gains}
\]



Untitled

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#after-tax-excess-return
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#after-tax-excess-return
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
After-tax excess return
The after-tax excess return (xâ€™) is computed as the after-tax return of the portfolio (Râ€™) minus the after-tax return of the benchmark (Bâ€™).
\[
x' = R' - B'
\]
data:image/svg+xml;supportsDarkMode=1;base64,
In this regard, the tax alpha would be defined as after-tax excess return (xâ€™) minus the pretax excess return (x).
\[
\alpha_{tax} = x' - x
\]

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#tax-efficiency-ratio-ter
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#tax-efficiency-ratio-ter
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Tax-efficiency ratio (TER)
The TER is calculated as after-tax return (Râ€™) divided by pretax return (R).
\[
TER = R' / R
\]
data:image/svg+xml;supportsDarkMode=1;base64,
For positive returns in taxable accounts, the higher the TER, the better. Obviously, the TER is not relevant for tax-exempt or tax-deferred accounts.
The TER does not work so well for negative returns, and in such instances, using an absolute comparison between after-tax and pretax returns or looking at tax alpha could be useful measurement alternatives.

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#taxable-tax-exempt-and-tax-deferred-accounts
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#taxable-tax-exempt-and-tax-deferred-accounts
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Taxable, tax-exempt, and tax-deferred accounts
Many countries offer accounts that allow funds to deposited and invested in a tax-advantaged manner. There are generally specified limits on how much can be invested in such accounts, and they are typically restricted to specified purposes such as retirement or health care.
Taxable accounts involve one or more tax rates on income (e.g., interest, dividends) or returns (e.g., realized capital gains) to determine R. The taxes per period are paid and represent a cash outflow. The after-tax future value (R) of the portfolio is then determine as follows, where n is the number of years:
data:image/svg+xml;supportsDarkMode=1;base64,
With tax-exempt accounts (TEA), after-tax funds are deposited so no tax is due on the returns earned or on withdrawals.
data:image/svg+xml;supportsDarkMode=1;base64,



Untitled


With tax-deferred accounts (TDAs), pretax funds are deposited, and the investor may take a tax deduction for the amount contributed, thereby reducing taxable income and taxes due. All tax is deferred until withdrawal, allowing tax-deferred compounding. Because no tax was paid on the funds deposited, tax is due on the full amount of withdrawals. The tax rate (t) will be the rate at the end of time n and the after-tax future value is calculated as follows:
data:image/svg+xml;supportsDarkMode=1;base64,
Superficially, it appears the TEA is superior to the TDA because there is no tax due on withdrawals. However, this ignores that TEA contributions are made with after-tax funds and TDA contributions are mad with pretax funds. Suppose an investor has $100 pretax available for savings and is in the $30 tax bracket. The full $100 can be contributed to a TDA and invested. If that contribution is not made, the investor will owe $30 in taxes now and have only $70 for contribution to the TEA.

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#asset-location
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#asset-location
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Asset location
which account?
The concept of asset location refers to whether to place asses in taxable, tax-exempt, or tax-deferred accounts. In general, tax-efficient assets (e.g., equities that generate capital gains, which are often subject to lower tax rates) should be place in taxable accounts and tax-inefficient assets (e.g., taxable bonds that generate taxable interest, which is often subject to higher tax rates) should be place in tax-exempt or tax-deferred accounts. However, exceptions may apply if equities held for the long term or subject to high turnover could avoid the negative and compounding effects of short-term taxes by being held in tax-exempt accounts and generating a comparatively higher after-tax return.
Bond â†’ regular coupon â†’ interest income tax â†’ TEA or TDA
Taxable accounts have the advantage of allowing losses incurred to be offset against gains earned (similar to tax loss harvesting). As well, in determining whether equities should be included in taxable versus tax-deferred accounts, consider the capital gains tax rate for the former and the tax rate upon withdrawal for the latter. For example, an overly low capital gains tax rate or an overly high marginal income tax rate at retirement would favor equities inclusion in taxable accounts. A low marginal income tax rate at retirement would generally favor equities inclusion in tax-deferred accounts.
For equity strategies, there is often the trade-off between passive strategies (more tax efficient due to low turnover and fewer transaction costs) versus active strategies (less tax efficient due to high turnover and more transaction costs) in that passive strategies often have lower returns than active strategies. In other words, there is a choice between 1) more tax efficiency and lower return and 2) less tax efficiency and higher return. (always higher after-tax return)



Untitled





Untitled

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#decumulation-strategies
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#decumulation-strategies
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Decumulation strategies
The natural progression is from capital accumulation during the working years to tax-efficient decumulation during the retirement years to cover a retireeâ€™s spending needs.
The advantageous tax impacts on returns for tax-exempt and tax-deferred accounts over taxable accounts means that withdrawals should occur from taxable accounts first until they are exhausted. This certainly true for a flat tax at all levels of income. In contrast, for a progressive tax system Â where marginal tax rates (ëˆ„ì§„ì„¸, ë§ˆì§€ë§‰ì— $ì— ì ìš©ëœ tax rate) increase with income, it would make sense to â€œuse upâ€ the lower tax brackets with withdrawals from tax-deferred accounts first.

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#charitable-giving-strategies
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#charitable-giving-strategies
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Charitable giving strategies
Charitable gifting has several key potential advantages:

For the giver, the capital gains upon transfer to qualifying charity of appreciated assets is deemed to be nil in some countries; in such instances, it is best to gift low-basis assets from taxable accounts.
For the giver, the fair market value of the gifted assets would qualify for a tax deduction/credit in some countries and that lowers personal taxes payable.
For the giver, if the assets are shares from a concentrated asset position, then the gift will lower the risk associated with the concentrated position.
For the receiver, because the charity is tax exempt, it will not pay tax on any investment income or gains related to the gifted assets.

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#tax-management-strategies
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#tax-management-strategies
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Tax management strategies
Investment held in a manner to minimize taxes

Allocating more to tax-exempt accounts than taxable accounts
Holding certain investments (e.g., equities) for sufficient time to be subject to lower capital gains tax rates.
Limiting dispositions to allow investments to earn more from tax-free compounding.
For progressive tax structures, waiting for marginal tax rates to fall when income levels are lower (e.g., retirement)
Tax loss harvesting-offsetting realized capital gains by deliberately selling investments that have embedded capital losses; this is an example where greater turnover may create a tax benefit.

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#investment-vehicles
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#investment-vehicles
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Investment vehicles
Four common vehicles include partnerships, mutual funds, exchange-traded funds (ETFs), and separately managed accounts (SMAs).

Partnership
Hedge funds and private equity funds are often structured as partnerships. Here, the partnership has no tax liability and taxes are usually allocated to the partners in the form of capital gains distributions, the latter of which are often taxed at lower rates.


Mutual fund
Investment income (e.g., dividends, interest) is allocated to the investors and tax is paid by the investors based on when the income was received. Capital gains tax arises if the investor disposes of the fund shares based on the excess of proceeds and tax basis.
In some countries, investors must pay their proportion of taxes for realized capital gains that occur within the fund. The fund net asset value (NAV) is lowered by the amount of the capital gains distribution.
New mutual fund shareholders may become liable for unrealized capital of prior periods. Consider an example of a fund that is established with 10 investors and assets of $20 million. Over time, with no trading nor change in investors, the assets have increased in value to $24 million, so there is a $4 million embedded gain. Therefore, each investor has a tax basis of $2 million and a share investment worth $2.4 million. Assuming one new investor comes in a invests $2.4 million, the fundâ€™s total tax basis is $22.4 million and the fundâ€™s NAV is $26.4 million. The new investor has a 1/11 ownership interest and the tax basis is $2036364 ($22.4 million/11). If the fund were immediately liquidated, the new investor would have a capital gains distribution of $363636 ($2400000 - $2035364) upon which there would be a tax liability. Therefore, the new investor is liable for taxes for which the investor did not benefit in terms of capital appreciation.
Measures such as the potential capital gain exposure (PCGE), calculated as net gains (losses) divided by total net assets, may provide some clues as the extent of embedded capital gains or untaxed capital appreciation in the fund that may become future tax liabilities for the investors. A high (low) PCGE suggests a high (low) likelihood of future capital gain distributions.


ETF
The ETF creation and redemption process is tax efficient because it allows managers the choice to transfer shares with a low cost basis to intermediaries (e.g., banks and brokerage firms). That will leave the ETF issuer with only the higher cost basis shares, which reduces the embedded capital gains and increases investorsâ€™ after-tax returns.


SMA
SMAs have the greatest potential for tax management because everything can be customized for only one investor.

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#tax-loss-harvesting
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#tax-loss-harvesting
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Tax loss harvesting
tax strategy
The concept of tax loss harvesting involves the sale of securities with embedded losses to offset gains, which will lower the tax liability for the current year.
One consideration for tax loss harvesting is the timing of sales in relation to the tax year-end. If a sale is being considered near the tax year-end, make the sale:

Before year-end if it is a loss in order to place the loss in the current tax year and offset gains this year. That will lower taxes payable this year but increase taxes payable in the following year.
After year-end if it is a gain. That will defer the gain and tax until the following year.

Watch out for situations where wash sale (or superficial loss) rules exist whereby, for example, losses may be denied if the same security is purchased 30 days before or after its sale at a loss. Circumventing the wash sale rules would require holding cash, an ETF, or a place holder security for 31 days, which may be inconsistent with the desired exposures. Also, the subsequent repurchase of the security after 31 days, likely at a lower cost, means that there will be higher future capital gains. This is an example of how tax loss harvesting is a form of tax deferral.
Many tax authorities allow a form of tax lot accounting. When an investor makes a partial sale and has acquired the stock on different dates, each at a different cost, the investor may select which tax lots applied to the sale (the specified-lot method). In that case, the tax lots that produce the lowest tax bill should be designated as sold. Consider an investor who bought 100 shares of stock on three different dates for $10000, $12000, and $15000. In this example, Â the investor just sold 100 shares.
Highest in, first out (HIFO) is generally optimal and the 100 shares with a cost basis of $15000 should be designated as sold. If the sales prices is higher than $15000, that will minimize the gain and capital gains tax due now.
In case future tax rates are expected to higher than current tax rates, first in, first out (FIFO) may be better and the 100 shares with a cost basis of $10000 should be designated as sold.

purchase price ìƒìŠ¹ ê°€ì •

In case future tax rates are expected to be lower than current tax rates, last in, first out (LIFO) may be better and the 100 shares with a cost basis of $15000 should be designated as sold.

purchase price ìƒìŠ¹ ê°€ì •

Because equity markets tend to appreciate over time, using LIFO is generally the most tax-efficient strategy. Here, the highest tax basis shares are sold first, which results in the lowest tax liability in the current period and defers the higher tax liabilities to future periods

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#quantitative-tax-management
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#quantitative-tax-management
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Quantitative tax management



Untitled


Risk and return are the basic principles in portfolio evaluation. In that regard, tracking error is used as a measure of the risk of introducing tax management and quantitative methods are used to maximize tax efficiency.
The general idea behind quantitative tax management is to minimize tracking error and trading costs as well as to minimize realized gains and maximize realized losses. The goal is to manage all the while meeting any other portfolio constraints (e.g., sector, country).
For new clients who transfer in appreciated securities, there is a delicate balance between the tax cost (e.g., realized gains) of selling those securities versus potential underperformance of holding those securities for too long. Those appreciated securities may not be consistent with the new investment objective.
Tax-optimized loss harvesting refers to looking for opportunities during the year as opposed to doing so only once near the end of the year. The assets that are sold during the process must be replace, and therefore, the process uses quantitative methods to determine appropriate replacement assets that would be consistent with the portfolioâ€™s investment objectives.
Gain-loss matching optimization can be used to achieve the goals of minimizing capital gains and ensuring risk exposures are in line with portfolio objectives. In other words, it is possible to have zero capital gains by not selling securities with embedded gains, but that may result in excessive concentration risk, for example.

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#concentrated-positions
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#concentrated-positions
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Concentrated positions



Untitled


Through work, inheritance, entrepreneurship, or for other reasons, individuals may come to hold concentrated positions in a single asset. Concentrated positions in a publicly traded single-stock position, a privately held business, or a real estate investment (not the primary residence) are covered in this module. A concentrated position may lead to inefficient asset allocation. An investment manager often works with the client to sell or otherwise monetize the asset.
A narrower definition of â€œconcentrated positionâ€ will be used here, referring to the inability to create a diversified and efficient portfolio resulting from low tax basis (e.g., large capital gains tax liability to be avoided) or emotional attachment.
Concentrated single-asset positions also have company-specific risk, which is the nonsystematic risk of an investment that can be diversified away.
Finally, concentrated positions could be subject to illiquidity and high transaction costs even if there is no tax due.
In choosing a strategy to manage the concentrated position, the following factors should be considered:

level of concentration-the higher it is, the timelier the response needs to be to reduce the risk
tax basis-the lower, the greater the taxes due
tax rate-the higher, the grater taxes due
liquidity-the more illiquid, the greater the costs of risk reduction
time horizon-more time may allow the concentration to be reduced gradually which lowers the overall cost
investor restrictions-may prevent an outright sale
nonfinancial matters-emotional attachments may hinder the risk-reduction process

Various strategies are available to manage concentrated positions, including:

sell the entire position-incur the tax liability and use the after-tax proceeds to invest in a more diversified manner
hedge and monetize-use derivatives to hedge (e.g., limit downside risk) and then borrow against its value and use the loan proceeds to accomplish client objectives.
Tax-free exchange funds-í˜„ë¬¼ì¶œì fund
charitable gifts-assets can be transferred to private foundations and donor-advised funds where such assets can be sold and not incur any tax liabilities. Those funds could be used to achieve the donorâ€™s charitable objectives.
Tax minimization strategies-some tax laws allow a tax-free step-up in basis if one holds an asset to death, which is a legal form of tax avoidance. A gradual disposition of a concentrated position spreads the tax liability out over a period of time and is an example of aÂ tax deferral strategy.
sell the entire position gradually over time-same as what was just listed but reduces risk of doing so at a suboptimal time.

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#staged-diversification-strategy
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#staged-diversification-strategy
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Staged diversification strategy
Here, the disposition of the concentrated position is not done all at once but is done over multiple years to spread out the tax liability accordingly.

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#completion-portfolio
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#completion-portfolio
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Completion portfolio
Here the other portfolio assets are structured for greatest diversification benefit to complement/complete the concentrated position. For example, if the concentrated position is an automobile stock, then the rest of the assets are selected to have a low correlation to auto mobile stocks such that the resulting total portfolio better tracks the return of the chosen benchmark.
On the tax side, quantitative techniques are used to determine how much rebalancing is required. There is both minimization of tracking error and maximization of after-tax return. Both objectives conflict because selling less shares at a time will reduce taxes but increase tracking error. In general terms, maximizing after-tax returns is achieved by realizing more capital losses and those capital losses are used to offset capital gains on the sale of the concentrated stock.

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#equity-monetization-collars-and-call-writing
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#equity-monetization-collars-and-call-writing
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
section: Equity monetization, collars, and call writing
text:
Equity monetization, collars, and call writing
Monetization generally involves receiving cash for a position without triggering a tax event. In other words, there is no disposition of the appreciated securities, and the investor still owns them. Monetization is a two-step process:

Hedge a large part of the risk in the position. This can be achieved with a short sale, forward sale contract, forward conversion with options, or a total return equity swap.
Borrow using the hedged position as collateral. The more effective the hedge, the higher the loan-to-value (LTV) ratio.

Zero-cost collars are a common way to lower initial cost by giving up some stock upside. A put is purchased and a call is sold with different strike prices selected so the premiums are equal.
Therefore, there is some risk reduction but not complete risk elimination. Also, for tax purposes, if the buy and sell premiums can be combined into one integrated transaction, it would be desirable, as it avoids any cash outflow associated with the taxation of the call premium income.
In terms of hedging, if a perfect hedge is used and removes all risk, it may be taxed as a sale (e.g., constructive sale). Therefore, the hedge must be structured to eliminate as much risk (and retain as little risk) as possible without the tax liability coming due.

constructive (ë§¤ê°ì˜ì œ) sale rule ì €ì´‰ì—¬ë¶€ check

Covered call writing is profitable strategy in stable markets if the stock price remains within a specific range, as the investor will imply keep the call option premiums received. Covered call writing could be viewed as a form of staged diversification but will only work if the share price appreciates sufficiently.



Untitled

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#tax-free-exchanges
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#tax-free-exchanges
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Tax-free exchanges
ë¬¼ë¬¼êµí™˜ fund
With an exchange fund, consider 10 investors, each of whom has a concentrated position in a single stock with a low cost basis. Each investorâ€™s position is in a different stock. The investor contributes a holding into a newly formed exchange fund and each investor now owns a pro rata share of the new fund. Investor H now participates in a diversified portfolio and defers any tax event until shares of the fund are sold.

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#charitable-remainder-trust
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#charitable-remainder-trust
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Charitable remainder trust
Here, the individual makes an irrevocable donation of the shares to a charitable remainder trust (CRT) and receives a tax deduction for the donation. From the donation (capital), Â the CRT as a tax-exempt entity could sell those shares for no tax consequences and reinvest the proceeds into a more diversified portfolio. From the portfolio, the CRT pays out income amounts to the designated beneficiaries and, upon the passing of the last beneficiary, the remainder of the capital goes to the designated charity.
OTC derivatives â†’ counterparty risk

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#privately-owned-businesses
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#privately-owned-businesses
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Privately owned businesses
exit strategy
The owner of the company usually has much of the personal wealth invested in the business, and the desire for liquidity must be balanced with dilution of ownership interest and possibly even loss of control.
Besides an initial public offering (IPO), direct sale to another investor (e.g., strategic buyer, financial buyer, management/key employees), or sale of non-essential business assets, three main strategies are considered here.

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#personal-line-of-credit-secured-by-company-shares
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#personal-line-of-credit-secured-by-company-shares
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
section: Personal line of credit secured by company shares
text:
Personal line of credit secured by company shares
The owner can borrow from the company and pledge company stock as collateral. The company may offer the lender a put, allowing the lender to transfer the loan to the company for cash.

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#leveraged-recapitalization
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#leveraged-recapitalization
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Leveraged recapitalization
The owner may retain 20%-40% for the equity capital and sell 60%-80% of the shares back to the company. The owner continues to manage the business with a significant financial stake. A private equity firm (PEF) could arrange the financing for the company to purchase the ownerâ€™s stock. In exchange, the PEF receives equity in the company. This can be part of a phased exit strategy; the owner will sell and receive cash for a portion of equity in the initial transaction and then participate in and sell remaining shares when the PEF resells their position in a few years. Taxes are owed on the cash received in the initial recapitalization but additional taxes are deferred until the ownerâ€™s remaining stock is sold.

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#employee-stock-ownership-plan-esop
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#employee-stock-ownership-plan-esop
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Employee stock ownership plan (ESOP)
ìš°ë¦¬ì‚¬ì£¼ì¡°í•©

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#real-estate
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#real-estate
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Real estate
property-specific risk for real estate is the direct counterparty to company-specific risk for a company.
A single investment in a real estate asset can be large and constitute a significant portion of an investorâ€™s assets, brining a high level of concentrated, property-specific risk. Real estate is generally illiquid and, if held for a long time, may have a significant unrealized capital gain.
Two key strategies to consider include mortgage financing and a donor-advised fund or charitable trust.

Mortgage financing
Normally, Â a sale of an income-producing property to an external party results in the immediate payment of capital gains taxes, loss of control, and no ability to benefit from future appreciation. Therefore, mortgage financing can be an attractive strategy to raise funds without suffering from any of those three negative effects.
With a nonrecourse loan (ë¹„ì†Œêµ¬ëŒ€ì¶œ), the lenderâ€™s only recourse is to seize the property if the loan is not paid. The borrower effectively has a put option on the property. If the property value falls below the loan amount, the borrower could simply default on the loan, keep the loan proceeds, and â€œputâ€ the property to the lender. A loan on income-producing property could have zero cash flow and zero tax effects on the borrower if the propertyâ€™s income covers the interest on the loan and other property expenses. The concentration risk is reduced because the loan proceeds could presumably be invested in liquid and diversified investments.
Mortgage financing with non-recourse loan
borrow

long put on the property
long call on the loanÂ prepayment option



Donor-advised fund (DAF) or charitable trust
A DAF can allow the property owner to take a tax deduction, gift more money to the charity, and influence the use of the donation. For example, an investor owns property worth $5 million and would like to make a $5 million contribution to a local hospital in exchange for having a new childrenâ€™s clinic named after his mother. The property was originally purchased for $3 million, and the investor has deducted $1.3 million of depreciation expense, making the current tax basis $1.7 million. If sold for $5 million, the investor would owe capital gains taxes on a $2 million capital gain and recapture taxes on $1.3 million ($3 million - $1.7 million). â†’ depreciation recapture taxes (ê°ê°€ìƒê° í™˜ì…ì„¸ê¸ˆ) Instead, the investor could contribute the property to a DAF for the hospital and take a $5 million tax deduction, and the tax-exempt hospital could sell or retain the property with no tax due.

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#gift-and-estate-planning
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#gift-and-estate-planning
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
gift and estate planning
An individualâ€™s estate is everything that is owned by the individual, including financial assets, real estate (immovable property), collections (e.g., art, stamps, coins), businesses, and intangible assets (e.g., trademarks, copyrights, patents).
Estate planning is the planning process associated with transferring the estate to others during an individualâ€™s lifetime or at death so that the assets go to the intended individuals or entities in the most efficient way (e.g., tax minimization).
Key objectives in gift and estate planning include the following.

Ensuring adequate liquidity and ongoing income


Control over assets
It is possible for the individual to provide beneficial ownership of the assets to the beneficiaries but not provide them with control of the assets, which is the same with charities-the individual donor may maintain control over the assets donated and direct how the funs are to be spent.


Asset protection
In some cases, trusts may shield assets from creditors as well as jurisdictions that provide statutory ownership that effectively gives one person the right to the assets of another. If the system has forced heirship rules, for example, children have a right to a portion of a parentâ€™s estate, regardless of the location of the child vis-a-vis the parent, the relationship that exists between the parent and child, or even the relationship between the parents.
forced heirship - ë²•ì •ìƒì†ê¶Œ



Untitled


Laws across the globe can vary dramatically. For example, a civil law system is based on old Roman law. In such a system, laws are handed down (i.e., a top-down system) by a legislative body. In contrast, a common law system, based primarily on old English law, is more â€œbottom up.â€ Judges play very important roles in common law systems by refining any existing laws to meet particular situations.

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#tax-effective-transfer-of-assets
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#tax-effective-transfer-of-assets
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Tax-effective transfer of assets
The two primary means of transferring assets are through gifts and bequests. Gifts transferred during oneâ€™s lifetime may be subject to gift tax, and bequests (transfer after death) may be subject to estate taxes paid by the grantor/transferor or inheritance taxes paid by the recipient. In many countries, there are tax-free allowances applying to gifts and transfers that would allow for the reduction of gift, estate, and inheritance taxes. (statutory allowance) A prudent financial plan would ensure all the available tax-free allowances are used as much as possible. Asset transfers before death are sometimes preferable, especially if the capital gains can be taxed at lower rates (e.g., beneficiaries).
In the absence of generation-skipping transfer taxes (GSTT), transferring assets directly to a third generation (e.g., grandparent directly to grandchild, bypassing the parent) avoids possible double taxation.



Untitled



Maintain family wealth
A family governance system may reduce or eliminate family disputes regarding investment and philanthropic objectives. The governance process is long term in nature, as it is meant to apply to the current and future generations. Items included in governance include trusts, foundations, and life insurance.


Business succession
Transferring control and ownership to the next generation of the family is done through gifts and bequests.


Charity
ì‹ì´ ì—†ëŠ” ê²½ìš° in general
Charitable donations may be tax effective when they fall under gift and/or estate tax exemptions.

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#general-estate-planning
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#general-estate-planning
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
General estate planning
The most common toll used to transfer assets is a will (or a testament).
Probate is a legal process that takes place at death, during which a court determines the validity of the decedentâ€™s will, inventories the decedentâ€™s property, resolves any claims against the decedent, and distributes remaining property according to the will.
Trusts are a common estate planning tool whereby the settlor establishes the trust by contributing assets and a trustee is assigned to maintain the assets for the beneficiaries designated by the settlor.

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#lifetime-gifts-and-testamentary-bequests
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#lifetime-gifts-and-testamentary-bequests
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Lifetime gifts and testamentary bequests
ìƒì „ ì¦ì—¬ì™€ ì‚¬í›„ ìƒì†



Untitled





Untitled


A client with excess capital (ì‚¬ëŠ”ë° í•„ìš”í•œ core capitalì„ ì œì™¸í•œ capital) may gift the capital now or bequeath it at death. Doing so now and making use of the tax-free exemptions is generally considered prudent because, had the gift not been made during the lifetime, the appreciated amount would be subject to future estate or inheritance tax. (technically deferring, justify questionì˜ answer) By gifting earlier, there are less amounts subject to future estate or inheritance tax. As well, assuming the giverâ€™s tax rate is higher than the receiverâ€™s tax rate, the resulting and periodic income generated by the gift (e.g., interest, dividends) would be subject to a lower tax rate.

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#charitable-gratuitous-transfers
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#charitable-gratuitous-transfers
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Charitable gratuitous transfers
There are three benefits of charitable gifts (e.g., appreciated securities):

The donor usually does not have to pay gift tax.
The donor receives an immediate tax deduction for the gift, which reduces the donorâ€™s current year tax liability.
The charity is usually tax exempt so it can invest the funds and there would be tax-free compounding.




Untitled

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#trusts
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#trusts
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Trusts
Trusts are a means by which a settlor (grantor) can transfer assets to beneficiaries outside of the probate process. The trustee (manager of the trust) holds the assets and manages them in the best interests of the beneficiaries according to the constraints of the trust documents. Trusts are recognized by, and are most prevalent in, common law countries.
Asset ownership can be a fuzzy concept with trusts. A trustee actually has possession of and manages the assets for the benefit of the settlor and/or beneficiaries and may be considered the owner of the assets for tax purposes only.
In a revocable trust, the settlor can rescind (revoke) the trust and resume ownership of the assets. The settlor is considered the legal owner of the assets for tax and reporting purposes, and persons such as creditors and divorcing spouses may make claims against the trust assets.
In an irrevocable trust, the settlor relinquishes ownership and control. The trustee is considered the owner of the assets for tax purposes and is responsible for Â reporting and paying taxes on income generated by the trust. The irrevocable trust protects the trust assets from claims against the settlor.
There are several reasons for using a trust:

Avoid giving control of assets to beneficiaries who would not be able to properly manage them.
Avoid dilution of ownership interest in a private business in countries where there is joint ownership and division of assets acquired during marriage.
Avoid probate.

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#foundations
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#foundations
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Foundations
Foundations are most prevalent in civil law countries and maintain assets to fund charitable causes. Types of foundations include private and family. Foundations generally provide the donor with control in managing the assets.

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#life-insurance
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#life-insurance
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Life insurance
wealth preservation
As the only assets transferred by the grantor (policyowner) are the premiums paid, life insurance policies represent a very efficient means for transferring assets or even helping beneficiaries pay inheritance taxes. In many jurisdictions, the premiums are not usually considered part of the grantorâ€™s estate for tax purposes.

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#companies
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#companies
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Companies
A controlled foreign corporation (CFC) is set up in a country outside of the investorâ€™s home country for which the investor may hold assets. (at tax haven) The investor would have a controlling interest in the company. It may be possible for the investment income earned in the CFC to escape taxation until the dividends are paid to the shareholder(s) or when the shares are sold. (single taxation)

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#family-governance
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#family-governance
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Family governance
ê°€ì—…ì§€ë°°êµ¬ì¡°
Family enterprises often go through the following cycle: first generation generates wealth, next generation holds onto the wealth, and the last generation spends it. Therefore, a robust system of family governance could reduce the negative outcomes.

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#governing-bodies-within-the-family
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#governing-bodies-within-the-family
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Governing bodies within the family

board of directors (BOD)
family council
family assembly
family office
family foundation

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#family-conflict-resolution
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#family-conflict-resolution
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Family conflict resolution
As conflicts are inevitable within families, it is important to have a clear family constitution in place.

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#business-succession-1
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#business-succession-1
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Business succession
Succession planning is usually focused on passing on the business to the next generation or simply selling it.

Passing the business on to the next generation
The founder may do a direct transfer or use a trust to pass on the shares to the next generation. It could be done before death or upon death. If done before death, the founder could elect to maintain ownership of the voting shares to maintain control and only transfer the nonvoting shares. Another possibility is to transfer the voting shares only to the active members of the business and transfer nonvoting shares to the nonactive members.

direct transfer
trust

Additionally, it is important that both the BOD and family council consist of members with diverse viewpoints to avoid social proof bias: it is the bias of â€œgoing with the flowâ€ without being completely informed of the important details that could impact the decision.


Disposition of the business
ì‚¬ì—…ì²­ì‚° â†’ endowment bias
Assuming there is no appropriate person(s) in the next generation to pass on the business, a sale of the business may be necessary. As discussed earlier in the behavioral finance section, endowment bias is likely to be an issue, which could overinflate the sellerâ€™s expectations.


Timing of the disposition
An estate freeze (ìƒì†ìì‚° ë™ê²° â†’ taxation strategy), establishing a limited partnership and gifting, or transferring to a trust may reduce taxes on future appreciation. Furthermore, the value of nonpublicly traded family business should be reduced to reflect lack of liquidity/marketability as well as reflect a minority interest discount if the ownership percentage sold does not provide control. The value reduction could result in lower gift and estate taxes.
father: GP / son: LP â†’ limited partnership structureëŠ” valuation discountë¥¼ ë°›ìŒ (liquidity, minority)


Choosing trustees
Appointed trustees could be individual or institutional.


After the disposition

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#planning-for-the-unexpected
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#planning-for-the-unexpected
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Planning for the unexpected

Divorce
The division of financial assets in the event of a marriage breakdown should be addressed in advance-that is often done through a prenuptial agreement (before marriage). Postnuptial agreement occur after the marriage is over and deal with financial matters after the marriage.


Incapacity
Living wills and durable powers of attorney (ìœ„ì„ì¥) can be used to address potential incapacity in the future.

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#human-capital
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#human-capital
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Human capital
Valuing human capital is analogous to valuing a stock or bond. Value is the discounted PV of future cash flows. The discount applied to the future cash flows is related to the riskiness of the cash flows. higher risk employment requires a higher discount rate and all else the same reduces the value of the HC.
stock-like â†’ high volatility
bond-like â†’ low volatility



Untitled


Financial capital is the value of all other assets owned by the individual.

real estate (other than publicly traded REITs) - A home if often an individualâ€™s largest single asset and may also be highly leveraged.
Annuities are economically equivalent to a private defined benefit plan in that they pay a continuing income stream. Their value should include some discount of future cash flows are reflect the potential the payer may default.

annuity - private pension (ì¼ì‹œë¶ˆ)

Cash-value life insurance is life insurance with a provision to borrow or take some present value portion of the future payout prior to death (which reduces the ultimate payout).

ì €ì¶•ì„± ë³´í—˜

Business assets or private equity may represent a substantial portion of wealth for some self employed individuals.
Collectables (such as paintings and book collections) often involve substantial transaction costs and can have elements of personal consumption and utility as well as investment value.
Pensions can be a significant non-marketable financial asset for some. the pension could be from a private or government entity.

ê°œì¸ í‡´ì§ì—°ê¸ˆ (IRP)
íšŒì‚¬ í‡´ì§ì—°ê¸ˆ (retirement pension)
êµ­ê°€ ì—°ê¸ˆ (government pension)

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#financial-stages-of-life
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#financial-stages-of-life
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Financial stages of life
Net worth is the sum of the individualâ€™s FC and HC less any liabilities owed by the individual. A typical individual might start an employment career with high HC and low FC. As remaining work career decreases with age, HC generally declines over time while FC increases as the individual saves and invests.

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#risks-and-insurance
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#risks-and-insurance
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Risks and insurance
Risk management for individuals requires:

Specifying the objective, which is to maximize household welfare (utility).
Identifying the risks to FC and HC. - mortality, longevity
Evaluating and managing those risks through:

Risk avoidance: choose actions to avoid the chance of the loss occurring. - fetal risk
Risk reduction - frequent risk
Risk transfer - derivatives, insurance
Risk retention

Monitoring results and adjusting as needed.

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#basic-life-insurance-terminology
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#basic-life-insurance-terminology
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Basic life insurance terminology

Benefits or face amount - The future payout. The terms may specify payout as a lump sum or an annuity. â†’ ìì‚°ì•„ë‹˜
Premium - The cost of the insurance.
Cash value - What the owner can withdraw before payout, which reduces or terminates final payout.
Paid up - A date when the insurance is fully paid for and no additional premiums are required. - ë³´í—˜ë£Œ ë‚©ì… ê¸°í•œ
Limitations - Restrictions on the payout of the insurance amount (e.g., misrepresentation of the health status of the insured leading to no payment). - ë©´ì±…ì¡°í•­
Contestability period - Time period for the insurance company to investigate or deny payment of the claim. - ë³´í—˜ê¸ˆì²­êµ¬ ì‹¬ì‚¬ê¸°ê°„
Identity of the insured - í”¼ë³´í—˜ì
policy owner - Responsible for making premium payments, often the insured. - ë³´í—˜ê³„ì•½ì
Beneficiaries - Receivers of the payout. - in general, statutory beneficiary.
Premium schedule - Amount and frequency of payments.
Riders - Additional provisions included in the policy. - ì¶”ê°€ì•½ê´€

objectID: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#annuities-1
href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#annuities-1
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Annuities
A basic annuity is a one-time premium payout in exchange for fixed payouts received for the life of the annuitant. The initial premium is the investment. When the annuity ends, the payouts cease.

The insurer collects the premium and makes the future payouts. (The insurer is often an insurance company, the company.)
The annuitant receives the annuity payouts in the future.
The contract owner pays the premium to purchase the annuity and is usually the annuitant.
The beneficiary receives any remaining value of the contract at death of the annuitant. In many cases, there is no beneficiary as payouts cease at death of the annuitant. - ë²•ì •ìƒì†ì¸
The premium, which is normally paid once at purchase, could also be referred to as the value of the contract. The premium paid to the company is the price of the annuity. However, the convention is to keep the premium constant and adjust the stated annual payout. This means that a lower/higher quoted payout to the annuitant is equivalent to a higher/lower price for the annuity.

href: posts/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management/CFA Level 3_Private Wealth Management.html#conclusion
title: CFA Level 3 Private Wealth Management
text:
Conclusion
Adding insurance tools provides more comprehensive risk management of HC and total wealth.

title: CFA Level 3 Alternative Investments
text:
Overview of hedge fund strategies
Key features that distinguish hedge funds from traditional investments include:

lower regulatory and legal constraints
flexibility to use short selling and derivatives
a larger investment universe
aggressive investment exposure
comparability free use of leverage
liquidity constraints for investors
lack of transparency
higher cost structures

title: CFA Level 3 Alternative Investments
text:
Classifications of hedge fund strategies
Hedge fund strategies are categorized based on the kinds of securities they invest in the trading strategy used, and the kinds of risk exposures taken.

Equity related
These fund strategies focus on stocks, and hence the primary source of risk is equity risk.

long/short equity
dedicated short bias
equity market neutral



Event driven
These hedge fund strategies relate to corporate actions such as governance activities, acquisitions, bankruptcies, and other major business events. The main risks of these strategies are event risk; the possibility that outcomes will not unfold as expected, including the failure of a merger, credit downgrades, or bankruptcy.

ë‚´ê°€ ì›í•˜ëŠ” ê²°ê³¼ê°€ ë‚˜ì˜¤ì§€ ì•Šì•˜ì„ ë•Œ ìœ„í—˜
M&A, distressedê°€ ì£¼ íƒ€ê²Ÿ
Merger arbitrage
Distressed securities



Relative value
These hedge fund strategies seek to profit from the relative valuation differences between securities. Credit and liquidity risks often complicate these strategies, because the valuation differences being exploited often related to securities with different credit quality or liquidity.

Credit/liquidity risk â†’ arbitrage

Two relative value strategies:

fixed income arbitrage
convertible bond arbitrage



Opportunistic
These strategies employ a top-down approach, often consider multiple asset classes, and vary with market conditions. The two opportunistic strategies that will be considered here are global macro and managed futures.

global macro
managed futures



Specialist
These hedge fund strategies often require specialized market expertise or knowledge. Often the risks of these strategies arise due to exposure to specific sectors or unusual securities. The two such specialist strategies we will consider in this topic review are volatility strategies and reinsurance strategies.

volatility strategy
reinsurance strategy



Multi-manager
These strategies use other hedge fund strategies as building blocks, combining different strategies together and rebalancing exposures over time. The two types of multi-manager hedge funds we will consider are multi-strategy funds and funds-of-funds.

multi-strategy funds
funds-of-funds

title: CFA Level 3 Alternative Investments
text:
Long/Short Equity
Long/short (L/S) equity hedge funds are straightforward to understand. The fund manager purchase (takes long positions in) stocks that they think will rise in value, and sells (takes short position in) stocks that they believe will fall in value.

L/S managerâ€™s traits

strategic focus
flexibility in holding L/S position overtime
use of leverage
small-cap and growth

positive exposure - size factor
negative exposure - value factor




The goal in L/S equity investing

find more source of idiosyncratic alpha
primarily via stock pricing, secondary by market timing rather than systematic beta



Deep-dive differentiated analysis needed for sector specific

telecommunication
financials
consumer
healthcare
biotech
ë•Œë•Œë¡œ generalist L/S managerëŠ” bio techê³¼ ê°™ì€ ê¸‰ê²©í•œ sectorëŠ” í”¼í•¨



Investment characteristics
When L/S equity managers combine long and short positions, the resulting L/S funds will typically have a 40%-60% net long exposure, which is beneficial considering that markets generally trend upward over time.
Many L/S equity managers aspire to provide returns comparable to that of a long-only fund but with half the amount of standard deviation.


Strategy implementation
Because successful implementation of an L/S equity strategy requires managers to identify overpriced and underpriced stocks, the majority of L/S equity funds take a sector-specific focus, choosing stocks from a particular industry that they are familiar with. They may also use index funds to achieve a desired exposure. L/S funds that are comparatively market neutral may need to use leverage to achieve worthwhile returns.


Role in a portfolio
The goal of most L/S equity managers is to attempt to source alpha from long and short exposures to single stocks, while also benefitting from a moderate overall long exposure.
When considering an investment is an L/S equity fund, one should consider whether the investment is worthwhile given the potentially high fees. Taking a traditional long-only equity position may be a more efficient way to achieve a comparable beta exposure.

title: CFA Level 3 Alternative Investments
text:
Dedicated short selling and short-biased
As the name suggested, dedicated short-selling funds seek out securities that are overpriced in order to sell them short. These managers look for poorly managed companies, firms in declining market segments, or even firms with deceitful accounting. Short-biased managers use a similar strategy, except that the short position is somewhat offset by a long exposure.
A notable subset of short selling is activist short selling, in which the fund manager not only takes a short position in a stock, but also presents research that contends that the stock is overpriced.

Beneish M-score to check fraudulent financial statement
